data.title: Dr. Robert H. Goddard
data.text: Dr. Robert H. Goddard A NY Times editorial excoriated Dr. Robert H. Goddard, and reported thatrockets can never fly. In 1969 the NY Times belatedly apologized.(WSJ, 8/7/03, p.A1)

data.title: The first liquid-fuel rocket
data.text: The first liquid-fuel rocket The first liquid-fuel rocket was launched by physicist Robert H. Goddard. Itwent 184' (56 meters). [see Mar 26](HN, 3/16/98)(MC, 3/16/02)

data.title: Pioneer physicist
data.text: Pioneer physicist and engineer Dr. Robert H. Goddard launched the first successfulliquid-fuel rocket in Auburn, Massachusetts. Goddard’s rocket,launched from a homemade pipe frame, rose 41 feet and in a2.5-second flight reached a speed of about 60 miles per hour,proving the practicality of liquid-propelled rocketry. [see Mar 16](HNPD, 3/14/99)

data.text: Virgil Grissom (d.1967), Lt. Col. USAF, astronaut (Mercury 4, Gemini 3), was bornin Mitchell, Ind. He was the Mercury and Gemini astronaut who waskilled in a fire while preparing for the first Apollo flight. http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/Apollo204/grissom.html(MC, 4/3/02)

data.title: In Germany the
data.text: In Germany the rocket-development team of Werner von Braun conducted the 1stsuccessful test flight of an A-4/V-2 missile from the Peenemundetest site. It flew perfectly over a 118-mile course to an altitudeof 53 miles (85 km). The 13-ton, 46-foot long V2 rocket was theworld’s 1st long-range ballistic missile.(HN, 10/3/98)(AM, 5/01, p.63)(WSJ, 2/21/09, p.A5)

data.title: The Space Age and
data.text: The Space Age and 'space race' began as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik (traveler),the first man-made space satellite. The satellite, built by ValentinGlushko, weighed 184 pounds and was launched by a convertedIntercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM). Sputnik, developed underthe chief scientist Sergei Korolyov, orbited the earth every 96minutes at a maximum height of 584 miles. The event was timed tocelebrate the 40th anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution. In 1958,it reentered the earth's atmosphere and burned up. It was followedby 9 other Sputnik spacecraft.(WSJ, 10/7/96, p.B4)(SFC, 8/2/97, p.A12)(SFEC,9/28/97, p.A14)(WSJ, 10/3/97, p.A8)(AP, 10/4/97)(HN, 10/4/98)(AP,10/1/07)

data.title: The Soviet Union
data.text: The Soviet Union launched into orbit Sputnik Two, the second manmade satellite; a dogon board named Laika, the first animal in space, was sacrificed inthe experiment. Sputnik 2 remained in orbit another 162 days beforeburning up. Safe reentry process had not yet been developed.(TMC, 1994, p.1957)(AP, 11/3/97)(HN, 11/3/98)

data.title: America's first
data.text: America's first attempt at putting a satellite into orbit failed as Vanguard TV3rose only about four feet off a Cape Canaveral, Fla., launch padbefore crashing back down and exploding.(AP, 12/6/08)

data.title: The United States
data.text: The United States successfully test-fired the Atlas intercontinental ballistic missilefor the first time. (AP, 12/17/97)

data.title: Explorer 1,
data.text: Explorer 1, the first successful US satellite, was launched by a Jupiter-Crocket and the United States entered the Space Age. It discoveredthe 'Van Allen radiation belts' around Earth named after James VanAllen. Radio signals from the transmitter aboard the 30.8 poundsatellite were picked up in California within a few minutes afterthe launch. Two months earlier, the first attempt to launch asatellite had failed.(SFEC, 9/28/97, p.A14)(AP, 1/31/98)(MC,1/31/02)

data.text: The U.S. Navy launched the Vanguard 1 satellite.(AP, 3/17/02)

Bloomfield, Major USAF, astronaut (STS 86), was born in Flint, Mich.(MC, 3/16/02)1959-Apr 9,NASA announced the selection of America's first seven astronauts forthe US first orbital flight in 1962 under the Mercury program: ScottCarpenter, Gordon Cooper, John Glenn, Gus Grissom, Wally Schirra,Alan Shepard and Donald Slayton.(SFC, 3/10/97, p.A16)(AP, 4/9/97)

data.title: The first balloon
data.text: The first balloon satellite, the Echo 1, was launched by the US from Cape Canaveral,Fla. It bounced phone calls from JPL in California to the Bell Labsin New Jersey.(AP, 8/12/97)(SFC, 4/9/02, p.A18)

data.title: Korabl-Sputnik-2
data.text: Korabl-Sputnik-2 (Spaceship Satellite-2), also known as Sputnik 5, was launched. Onboard were the dogs Belka (Squirrel) and Strelka (Little Arrow).Also on board were 40 mice, 2 rats and a variety of plants. After aday in orbit, the spacecraft's retrorocket was fired and the landingcapsule and the dogs were safely recovered. They were the firstliving animals to survive orbital flight.(www.spacetoday.org/Astronauts/Animals/Dogs.html)

data.title: Discoverer XVII
data.text: Discoverer XVII was launched into orbit from California’s Vandenberg AFB.TheDiscoverer Program (1959-1962) was a ruse to conceal the CoronaProgram, a series of photoreconnaissance spy satellites. Corona wasthe first photoreconnaissance program, and a precursor of themilitary and civilian space imaging programs of today.(HN,11/12/98)(http://spacecovers.com/pricelists/categories/category_satellites.htm)

data.title: Chimpanzee Ham
data.text: Chimpanzee Ham landed safely and became the 1st primate in space after a 16 minuteflight aboard a Mercury-Redstone 2 rocket.(AH, 2/06, p.14)

data.title: The United States
data.text: The United States launched the “Explorer Nine' satellite.(AP, 2/16/01)1961Mar 9, Korabl-Sputnik-4, also known as Sputnik 9, was launched witha dog named Chernushka (Blackie) on a one orbit mission. Alsoonboard the spacecraft was a dummy cosmonaut, mice and a guinea pig.(www.spacetoday.org/Astronauts/Animals/Dogs.html)

data.title: Sputnik 10 carried
data.text: Sputnik 10 carried a dog into Earth orbit; later recovered.(MC, 3/25/02)

data.title: Yuri Alexeyevich
data.text: Yuri Alexeyevich Gagarin, Russian cosmonaut, experienced the weightlessness of spacefor 108 minutes. He orbited the Earth once before making a safelanding. The Russians rocketed Yuri Gagarin, the first man intospace. His ship, Vostok I, was guided entirely from the ground.(SFEC, 2/16/97, Z1 p.6)(AP, 4/12/97)(HN,4/12/98)(NPub, 2002, p.20)

data.title: Astronaut Alan
data.text: Astronaut Alan Bartlett Shepard Jr. (d.1998 at 74), a Navy commander, became thefirst American in space as he made a 15-minute suborbital flight inthe Freedom 7 Project Mercury capsule launched from Cape Canaveral,Fla. The spacecraft reached a maximum altitude of 116.5 miles.(AP, 5/5/97)(HN, 5/5/98)(SFC, 7/23/98, p.A1)(HNQ,7/11/99)

data.text: President Kennedy summoned a joint session of Congress and asked the nation to worktoward putting a man on the moon by the end of the decade. In 2011John Logsdon authored “John F. Kennedy and the Race to the Moon.'(AP, 5/25/97)(Econ, 5/21/11, p.36)

data.text: Capt. Virgil 'Gus' Grissom became the second American to rocket into a suborbitalpattern around the Earth, flying on the Mercury 4 Liberty Bell 7.The Mercury capsule sank in the Atlantic, 302 miles from CapeCanaveral and Grissom was rescued by helicopter. data.title: the first astro chimpanzee Ham
data.text: the first astro chimpanzee Ham the first astro chimpanzee, was named for the Holloman Aeromedical Laboratory. Heproved space travel was safe for humans when he flew aboard aMercury capsule.(WSJ, 12/30/97, p.A1)

data.title: U.S. Marine
data.text: U.S. Marine Lieutenant Colonel John H. Glenn, Jr. (1921-2016), became the firstAmerican to orbit the earth. Launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla.,Glenn made three 90-minute orbits of the earth in Friendship 7,radioing down to Earth, 'Oh, that view is tremendous!' When theship's automatic altitude control system began to fail, Glenn, adecorated WW II pilot, took manual control for the rest of theflight. During Friendship 7's approach to Earth, Glenn saw someflaming material breaking off the capsule, but the parachute openedand the capsule landed safely in the Atlantic Ocean. It was sometime later that NASA mission control determined that the sparks werecrystallized water vapor released by Friendship 7's air-conditioningsystem. Friendship 7's flight lasted four hours and 56 minutes. (AP, 2/19/98)(HNPD, 2/20/99)(SFC, 12/9/16, p.A12)

data.title: The United States
data.text: The United States launched the Mariner 2 space probe with an Atlas D booster. OnDecember 14, 1962, Mariner 2 passed within just over 20,000 miles ofVenus, reporting an 800F surface temperature, high surfacepressures, a predominantly carbon dioxide atmosphere, continuouscloud cover, and no detectable magnetic field.(AP, 8/27/97)(SFEM, 8/22/99,p.9)(http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/tmp/1962-041A.html)

data.text: Transit 5A1, the 1st operational navigational satellite, was launched.(MC, 12/19/01)1962-NASA ended its Mercury 13program. In 2003 Martha Ackermann authored 'The Mercury 13: TheUntold Story of the Thirteen American Women and the Dream of SpaceFlight.'(SSFC, 6/15/03, p.M4)

data.text: After 22 Earth orbits Gordon Cooper returned to Earth in Friendship Seven, endingProject Mercury.(HN, 5/16/98)

data.text: The Soviet Union launched a Voskhod space capsule with a three-man crew on the firstmanned mission involving more than one crew member. data.title: America's first
data.text: America's first two-person space flight began as Gemini 3 blasted off from CapeKennedy with astronauts Virgil I. Grissom and John W. Young aboardfor a nearly five-hour flight. data.title: Two U.S. manned

data.title: The Borman and
data.text: The Borman and Lovell splash down in the Atlantic ended a 2 week Gemini VIImission.(MC, 12/18/01)

data.title: The Soviets
data.text: The Soviets launched Luna 9, the first spacecraft to land softly on the moon.(HC, 2003, p.64)

data.title: The Soviet probe
data.text: The Soviet probe Luna 9 became the first manmade object to make a soft landing on themoon.(AP, 2/3/08)

data.title: 1966 Mar 17, US
data.text: 1966 Mar 17, US astronauts Neil Armstrong and David Scott performed the firstorbital docking.(NPub, 2002, p.20)

data.title: Gemini astronaut
data.text: Gemini astronaut Gene Cernan attempted to become the first man to orbit the Earthuntethered to a space capsule, but was unable to when he exhaustshimself fitting into his rocket pack. (HN, 6/8/99)

data.title: Gemini X returned
data.text: Gemini X returned to Earth.(OGA, 11/24/98)

data.title: Pioneer 7 launched
data.text: Pioneer 7 launched into solar orbit.(SC, 8/17/02)

data.title: Gemini XI, a 3-day
data.text: Gemini XI, a 3-day mission, was launched with Charles Conrad in command.(SFC, 7/9/99, p.A6)

data.title: USSR launched Luna
data.text: USSR launched Luna 13. It soft-landed on the Moon’s Oceanus Procellarum.(MC, 12/21/01)

data.title: Soviet research
data.text: Soviet research station Luna 13 soft-landed on the moon. (HN, 12/24/98)(MC, 12/24/01)1966-NASA was spending 4.4% ofthe American government’s budget providing jobs for some 400,000people.(Economist, 9/1/12, p.90)

data.title: The US signed a
data.text: The US signed a space treaty with Russia. More than 60 nations signed a treatybanning the orbiting of nuclear weapons. (SFC, 1/28/67, p.A1)(AP, 1/27/98)

data.title: During a launch
data.text: During a launch pad test of the Apollo I (AS-204) mission at Cape Kennedy, a flashfire suddenly broke out in the vehicle's command module and killedits crew, Lt. Col. Edward White, II (U.S. Air Force), Lt. Col.Virgil 'Gus' Grissom (U.S. Air Force) and Lt. Cmdr. Roger Chaffee(U.S. Navy), pictured above. The fire consumed the command modulemere seconds after the crew had reported it. Although the Apollo Itest ended in tragedy, subsequent modifications to safety andplanning contributed to the success of later Apollomissions--including the first landing on the moon and the first timea man walked on the moon.(AP, 1/27/98)(HNPD, 1/27/99)

data.title: Ten Minuteman
data.text: Ten Minuteman missiles were mysteriously deactivated at a Montana missile base asan alleged UFO hovered overhead. (http://www.wanttoknow.info/ufos/ufos_national_press_club_witness_testimony)

data.title: Soyuz 1 was
data.text: Soyuz 1 was launched, and Vladimir Komarov became the first in-flight casualty.(AP, 4/23/98)

data.title: Venera 4, a space
data.text: Venera 4, a space probe of the Soviet Union, was launched. It transmitted informationon the atmosphere of Venus.(SFEC, 9/28/97,p.A14)(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venera_4)

data.title: NASA (National
data.text: NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration) launched Apollo 4 into orbitfrom Cape Kennedy with the first successful test of a Saturn Vrocket. (AP, 11/9/97)(HN, 11/9/98)

data.title: Apollo 5 was
data.text: Apollo 5 was launched to the Moon from Cape Canaveral, Florida.(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_5)

data.title: The USSR launched
data.text: The USSR launched space probe Zond 4. It failed to leave Earth orbit.(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zond_4)

data.title: NASA launched its
data.text: NASA launched its Orbiting Geophysical Observatory 5.(http://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/docs/heasarc/missions/ogo.html)

data.title: Neil Armstrong was
data.text: Neil Armstrong was nearly killed in a lunar module trainer accident.(HNQ, 7/20/99)

data.title: William Dana
data.text: William Dana reached 80 km. in the last high-altitude X-15 flight.(SC, 8/21/02)

data.title: Apollo 7, The
data.text: Apollo 7, The first manned Apollo mission, was launched from Cape Kennedy withastronauts Wally Schirra, Donn Fulton Eisele and R. WalterCunningham aboard. It made 163 orbits in 260 hours.(AP,10/11/97)(www.apollomissionphotos.com/index_AP7.html)

data.title: The first live
data.text: The first live telecast from a manned US spacecraft was sent from Apollo 7.(AP, 10/14/98)

data.title: The first orbiting
data.text: The first orbiting astronomical observatory, OAO-2, was launched.(SFEC, 9/28/97, p.A14)

data.title: Apollo 8 with
data.text: Apollo 8 with astronauts Borman, Lovell & Anders was launched on the 1stmission to orbit the moon.(AP,12/21/97)(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_8)

data.title: The 3 Apollo 8
data.text: The 3 Apollo 8 astronauts, orbiting the moon, read passages from the Old TestamentBook of Genesis during a Christmas Eve television broadcast. Thefirst pictures of an Earth-rise over the Moon are seen as the crewof Apollo 8 orbits the moon.(TL, 1988, p.117)(AP, 12/24/97)(HN, 12/24/99)

data.title: Apollo 8, the 1st
data.text: Apollo 8, the 1st manned mission to the moon, and its three astronauts made a safe,nighttime splashdown in the Pacific. (AP,12/27/97)(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_8)

data.title: The Russian Soyuz
data.text: The Russian Soyuz 5 went into orbit. The crew then maneuvered to dock with Soyuz 4 andYevgeny Khrunov (d.2000 at 67) became the first astronaut totransfer between linked capsules.(SFC, 5/27/00, p.A26)

data.title: Apollo 9 blasted
data.text: Apollo 9 blasted off from Cape Kennedy on a mission to test the lunar module. Itcarried astronauts James McDivitt, Russell Schweickart and DavidScott and made 151 Earth orbits over 10 days.(AP, 3/3/98)(SSFC, 3/8/09, p.B2)

data.title: The Apollo 9
data.text: The Apollo 9 astronauts splashed down, ending a mission that included thesuccessful testing of the lunar module. (AP, 3/13/97)

data.title: Russia’s Venera 5
data.text: Russia’s Venera 5 landed on Venus and returned data on atmosphere.(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venera_5)

data.title: Astronauts Eugene
data.text: Astronauts Eugene A. Cernan, Thomas P. Stafford and John W. Young blasted off aboardApollo 10. (AP, 5/18/97)

data.title: The lunar module
data.text: The lunar module of Apollo 10 separated from the command module and flew to withinnine miles of the moon's surface in a dress rehearsal for the firstlunar landing.(AP, 5/22/97)

data.title: The Apollo 10
data.text: The Apollo 10 astronauts returned to Earth after a successful eight-day dressrehearsal for the first manned moon landing. (AP, 5/26/97)(HN, 5/26/98)

data.title: Apollo XI set out
data.text: Apollo XI set out from Cape Canaveral (Cape Kennedy), Florida, with Neil Armstrong,Edwin Aldrin, and Michael Collins on the first manned mission to thesurface of the moon. Engineer George Mueller (1918-2015) served ashead of manned space flight at NASA.(V.D.-H.K.p.182, 341)(AP, 7/16/97)(SFC, 10/22/15,p.D3)

data.title: Apollo 11 and its
data.text: Apollo 11 and its astronauts, Neil Armstrong, Edwin 'Buzz' Aldrin and Michael Collins,went into orbit around the moon. (AP, 7/19/99)

data.title: Astronaut Neil
data.text: Astronaut Neil Armstrong took his legendary 'one small step for man, one giant leapfor mankind.' He and Edwin 'Buzz' Aldrin made the first successfullanding of a manned vehicle on the moon when they touched down inApollo 11. Armstrong stepped down from the ladder of the landingmodule Eagle to become the first man ever to walk on the moon. Thetwo astronauts explored the moon's surface for 2 1/2 hours, withamazed TV audiences looking on. Armstrong was awarded thePresidential Medal of Freedom for his accomplishments and hiscontributions to the space program. Edwin Aldrin became the secondman to step foot on the moon shortly after Neil Armstrong hopped offthe lunar lander Eagle at 10:56 p.m. Armstrong and Aldrin walked onthe moon for about two hours during their 22-hour lunar stay. ThomasKelly (d.2002 at 72) was the engineer who had overseen the buildingof the lunar module.(V.D.-H.K.p.182, 341) (TMC, 1994, p.1969)(AP,7/20/97)(HNPD, 7/20/98)(HNQ, 9/14/00)(SFC, 3/29/02, p.A24)

data.title: Apollo 11
data.text: Apollo 11 astronauts Neil Armstrong and Edwin 'Buzz' Aldrin blasted off fromthe moon aboard the lunar module.(AP, 7/21/99)

data.title: The Apollo XI
data.text: The Apollo XI astronauts, two of whom had been the first men to set foot on themoon, splashed down safely in the Pacific. They were picked up bythe 42,000 ton USS Hornet. The Hornet was decommissioned in 1970 andset up as a museum in 1998 in Alameda, Ca.(V.D.-H.K.p.182, 341)(AP, 7/24/97)(SFC, 8/17/98,p.A22)

data.title: The United States
data.text: The United States launched Apollo 12 for the moon from Cape Kennedy.(AP, 11/14/97)(HN, 11/14/98)

data.title: Apollo 12
data.text: Apollo 12 astronauts Charles Conrad and Alan Bean made man's second landing onthe moon. (AP, 11/19/97)(HN, 11/19/98)

data.title: Apollo XII
data.text: Apollo XII returned to Earth.(SFC, 7/9/99, p.A6)

data.title: Japan launched its
data.text: Japan launched its first satellite, Ohsumi-1. That launch made Japan the fourth nationwith a space rocket powerful enough to launch satellites to Earthorbit, after the USSR, the US and France.(www.spacetoday.org/Japan/Japan/History.html)

data.title: Apollo 13 blasted
data.text: Apollo 13 blasted off on a mission to the moon, commanded by Jim Lovell, that wasdisrupted on April 13, when an explosion crippled the spacecraft.The astronauts managed to return safely on April 17.(AP, 4/11/97)(AWAM, Dec. 94, p.79)(TMC, 1994,p.1970)

data.title: Apollo 13,
data.text: Apollo 13, four-fifths of the way to the moon, was crippled when a tankcontaining liquid oxygen burst: 'Houston, we've got a problem!' Theincident preventing a planned moon landing. The three-man crewmanaged to return safely.(AP, 4/13/97)(HN, 4/13/98)(HN, 4/13/99)

data.title: The Apollo 13 crew
data.text: The Apollo 13 crew splashed down safely in the Pacific, four days after a rupturedoxygen tank crippled their spacecraft. A film was made in 1995 thatdepicted the mission.(WSJ, 3/22/96, p.A-12)(SFEC, 11/10/96, Parp.5)(AP, 4/17/97)

data.title: China launched its
data.text: China launched its first satellite, known as China 1 or Mao 1, to orbit on a Long Marchrocket. It was the fifth nation able to launch its own satellite toorbit.(www.spacetoday.org/Satellites/Iran/IranianSat.html)

data.title: A. Nikolayev and
data.text: A. Nikolayev and V. Sevastyanov returned after 18 days in Russia’s Soyuz 9.(www.astronautix.com/flights/soyuz9.htm)

data.title: Venera 7 was
data.text: Venera 7 was launched by USSR for a soft landing on Venus.(SC, 8/17/02)

data.title: The Soviet Union
data.text: The Soviet Union launched its unmanned Soviet Luna 16. It was the first robotic probeto land on the Moon and return a sample to Earth.(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luna_16)

data.title: The Soviet Luna 16
data.text: The Soviet Luna 16 landed on Moon’s Mare Fecunditatis and drilled a core sample.(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luna_16)

data.title: The Soviet Luna 16
data.text: The Soviet Luna 16 landed in Kazakhstan, completing the first unmanned round trip tothe moon.(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luna_16)

data.title: The X24A lifting
data.text: The X24A lifting body exceeded Mach 1. The X-24A was the Martin Corporation'ssubsonic test version of the US Air Force's preferred manned liftingbody configuration. The lifting bodies were used to demonstrate theability of pilots to maneuver and safely land wingless vehiclesdesigned to fly back to Earth from space and be landed like anairplane at a predetermined site.(NPub, 2002,p.22)(www.dfrc.nasa.gov/Gallery/Movie/X-24A/index.html)

data.title: The Soviet Union
data.text: The Soviet Union landed an unmanned, remote-controlled vehicle on the moon, theLunokhod 1. The spacecraft which carried Lunokhod 1 was named Luna17.(AP,11/17/97)(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lunokhod_1)

data.title: Apollo 14 lander
data.text: Apollo 14 lander Antares landed on Moon with Shepard & Mitchell.(MC, 2/4/02)

data.title: The 'Apollo 14'
data.text: The 'Apollo 14' spacecraft returned to Earth after man's third landing on the moon.(AP, 2/9/99)

data.title: The Soviet Union
data.text: The Soviet Union launched Salyut 1, the world’s first space station into orbit. (HN,4/19/97)(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salyut_1)

data.title: The Soviet Union
data.text: The Soviet Union launched Soyuz 10; the cosmonauts became the first in Salyut 1 spacestation.(HN,4/23/02)(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soyuz_10)

data.title: The KOSMOS 419
data.text: The KOSMOS 419 Probe failed to leave Earth orbit.(SFC, 11/19/96, p.B1)

data.title: The Mars 2 Orbiter
data.text: The Mars 2 Orbiter and Lander made it to Mars but the Lander crashed when brakingrockets failed. The orbiter returned in 1972.(SFC, 11/19/96, p.B1)

data.title: The Mars 3 Orbiter
data.text: The Mars 3 Orbiter and lander was launched successfully.(SFC, 11/19/96, p.B1)

data.title: Soviet Soyuz 11
data.text: Soviet Soyuz 11 crew completed the 1st transfer to orbiting Salyut.(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salyut_1)

data.title: A Soviet space
data.text: A Soviet space mission ended in tragedy when three cosmonauts (Georgi Dobrovolsky,Vladislav Volkov, and Viktor Patsayev) aboard Soyuz 11 were founddead inside their spacecraft after it returned to Earth. (AP, 6/30/97)(SFC, 10/2/07, p.A6)

data.title: Apollo 15 was
data.text: Apollo 15 was launched from Cape Kennedy.(AP, 7/26/97)

data.title: US Apollo 15 with
data.text: US Apollo 15 with astronauts Scott and Irwin landed at Mare Imbrium on the Moon.(http://history.nasa.gov/SP-362/app.b.htm)

data.title: Apollo 15
data.text: Apollo 15 astronauts (Dave Scott) took a drive on the moon in their landrover.(HN, 7/31/98)(MC, 8/31/01)

data.title: The US space probe
data.text: The US space probe Mariner 9 went into orbit around Mars. NASA's Mariner 9 circled Marsand revealed dried beds of rivers that flowed billions of years ago.(SFC, 8/7/96, p.A9)(TMC, 1994, p.1971)(AP,11/13/01)1971-The US Bureau of Alcohol,Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) branded ammonium perchloratecomposite propellant (APCP) as a low explosive. The substance, usedas a rocket propellant by NASA, was also used by rocket hobbyists.(WSJ, 5/7/04,p.A1)(http://seattlepi.nwsource.com/local/113159_rockets19.shtml)

data.title: Pioneer 10 was
data.text: Pioneer 10 was launched from Cape Kennedy. It carried a plaque designed by CarlSagan and Frank Drake showing some details of human civilization onEarth. The craft headed to Jupiter and then continued into deepspace long past expectations. In 2001 contact was re-establishedwith the craft 7.29 billion miles distant and enroute toward theconstellation Taurus. Contact was again made in 2002. Pioneer wasexpected to reach the red star Aldebaran in Taurus in about 2million years.(SFC, 3/4/96, p.A5)(SFEC, 9/28/97, p.A14)(SFC,4/30/01, p.A7)

data.title: Apollo 16 blasted
data.text: Apollo 16 blasted off on a voyage to the moon.(AP, 4/16/97)

data.title: The manned lunar
data.text: The manned lunar module from Apollo 16 landed on the moon.(AP, 4/20/97)

data.title: NASA launched the
data.text: NASA launched the Landsat-1 satellite. It viewed Earth at different wavelengths andopened a new era in sensing the planet’s resources and environment.(SFEC, 9/28/97, p.A14)

data.title: US orbiting
data.text: US orbiting astronomy observatory Copernicus was launched.(SC, 8/21/02)

data.title: Apollo 16
data.text: Apollo 16 astronauts John Young and Charles Duke explored the surface of themoon with Boeing Lunar Rover #2.(AP, 4/21/97)

data.title: Apollo 16 returned
data.text: Apollo 16 returned to Earth.(www.solarviews.com/eng/apo16.htm)

data.title: America's last moon
data.text: America's last moon mission to date was launched as Apollo 17 blasted off from CapeCanaveral at 12:33 a.m. It landed on the moon December 11 at 3:15p.m. and took a historic photo of the Earth that showed our'isolated blue planet.'(AP, 12/7/97)(SFC, 3/13/98, p.A19)(HNQ, 7/21/99)

data.title: Challenger, the
data.text: Challenger, the Lunar Lander for Apollo 17, touched down on the Moon's surface. Itwas the last time that men visited the Moon. The last two men towalk on the surface of the moon were Harrison Schmitt and EugeneCernan. Cernan and Schmitt conducted the longest lunar explorationof the Apollo program (75 hours), driving the lunar rover about 36kilometers (22 miles) in all, ranging as far as 7.37 kilometers (4.5miles) from the lunar module Challenger and collecting some 243pounds of soil and rock samples.(HNQ, 7/21/99)(HN, 12/11/99)

data.title: Astronauts Schmitt
data.text: Astronauts Schmitt and Cernan blasted off from the moon to join the command moduleAmerica in lunar orbit, thus ending America’s manned lunarexploration for the 20th century. Apollo 17 astronauts blasted offfrom the moon after three days of exploration on lunar surface.(HNQ, 7/21/99)(AP, 12/14/02)

data.title: Apollo 17 splashed
data.text: Apollo 17 splashed down in the Pacific, ending the Apollo program of manned lunarlandings. (AP, 12/19/97)

data.title: Pioneer 11, built
data.text: Pioneer 11, built to be a backup if Pioneer 10 failed, was launched from Kennedy SpaceCenter in Florida, on an Atlas-Centaur rocket, on a trajectorysimilar to Pioneer 10. After Pioneer 10 completed the first eversuccessful encounter with Jupiter, Pioneer 11 was re-targeted, evenwhile it was flying outward, for an eventual encounter with Saturnafter its visit to Jupiter in December, 1973.(http://www.spacetoday.org/SolSys/ThePioneers.html)

data.title: The United States
data.text: The United States launched the 85-ton Skylab 1, its first manned space station withcrew Kerwin, Conrad and Paul J. Weitz (1932-2017). (AP,5/14/97)(SFC, 10/25/17, p.D7)

data.title: The Russian Mars 4
data.text: The Russian Mars 4 Orbiter braking engine malfunctioned and it failed to go into orbitaround Mars.(SFC, 11/19/96,p.B1)(http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/masterCatalog.do?sc=1973-047A)

data.title: Russia launched
data.text: Russia launched its Mars 5 Orbiter.(http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/masterCatalog.do?sc=1973-049A)

data.title: Astronauts Alan
data.text: Astronauts Alan Bean, Owen Garriott & Jack Lousma) launched to continuemaintenance at Skylab 3.(www.astronautix.com/flights/skylab3.htm)

data.title: The Intelsat
data.text: The Intelsat communications satellite was launched.(MC, 8/23/02)

data.title: The three-man crew
data.text: The three-man crew of the U.S. space laboratory Skylab Two splashed down safely in thePacific Ocean after spending 59 days in orbit. (AP, 9/25/98)

data.title: Pioneer 10 passed
data.text: Pioneer 10 passed Jupiter in the 1st fly-by of an outer planet.(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneer_10)

data.title: Skylab astronauts
data.text: Skylab astronauts took a seven hour walk in space and photographed the comet Kohoutek.(HN, 12/25/98)

data.title: The three-man crew
data.text: The three-man crew of 'Skylab' space station returned to Earth after spending 84 daysin space. (AP, 2/8/99)

data.title: US Mariner 10 made
data.text: US Mariner 10 made a 2nd fly-by of Mercury.(NH, 5/01,p.38)(www.astronautix.com/craft/marner10.htm)

data.title: Pioneer II made its
data.text: Pioneer II made its closest approach to Jupiter.(www.astronautix.com/project/pioneer.htm)

data.title: India announced it
data.text: India announced it had launched its 1st satellite, from the Soviet Union atop a Sovietrocket.(AP, 4/19/05)

data.title: Three American
data.text: Three American astronauts blasted off aboard an Apollo spaceship hours after twoSoviet cosmonauts were launched aboard a Soyuz spacecraft for amission that included a linkup of the two ships in orbit.(AP, 7/15/97)

data.title: A US Apollo
data.text: A US Apollo spaceship docked with a Soyuz spacecraft in orbit in the firstsuperpower linkup of its kind. Soviet cosmonauts Valery Kubasov(1935-2014) and lt. Col. Alexei A. Leonov spent 44 hours with Brig.Gen. Thomas P. Stafford, Deke Slayton and Vance D. Brand.(AP, 7/17/97)(SFC, 3/3/14, p.D2)

data.title: The Apollo and
data.text: The Apollo and Soyuz space capsules that were linked in orbit for two daysseparated. (AP, 7/19/97)

data.title: An 'Apollo'
data.text: An 'Apollo' spacecraft splashed down in the Pacific, completing a mission whichincluded the first-ever docking with a 'Soyuz' capsule from theSoviet Union. (AP, 7/24/00)

data.title: Viking 1, the
data.text: Viking 1, the first of 2 unmanned Viking landers, was launched from CapeCanaveral, Florida, on a mission to Mars. It reached Mars in thesummer of 1976.(SFEC, 9/28/97, p.A14)1975-A Russian SL3 rocket bodybegan orbiting the Earth. It re-entered the atmosphere in 2001.(SFC, 9/7/01, p.A12)

data.title: Eleanor Helin of
data.text: Eleanor Helin of NASA’s Jet Propulsion Lab. discovered the first near Earth asteroidwhich she named Aten. The orbits of these asteroids lie mostlyinside that of the Earth and could at some date collide with theEarth.{NASA, Asteroid, USA}(SFC, 2/1/97,p.A8)(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eleanor_F._Helin)

data.title: The Viking I robot
data.text: The Viking I robot spacecraft made a successful, first-ever landing on Mars and begantaking soil samples.(AP, 7/20/97)(HN, 7/20/98)

data.title: Scientists in
data.text: Scientists in Pasadena, Calif., announced that the Viking 1 spacecraft had foundthe strongest indications to date of possible life on Mars. (AP, 8/7/97)

data.title: NASA publicly
data.text: NASA publicly unveiled the space shuttle Enterprise at ceremonies in Palmdale,Calif. (AP, 9/17/97)(HN, 9/17/98)1976-Baruch S. Blumberg(1925-2011) of NASA Ames Astrobiology Inst. won the Nobel Prize inmedicine or physiology. He had discovered a virus that causedhepatitis and a vaccine to prevent it.(SFC, 10/8/01, p.A17)(Econ, 4/30/11, p.92)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Enterprise, sitting atop a Boeing 747, went on its maiden 'flight'above the Mojave Desert. (AP, 2/18/98)

data.title: Werner von Braun obituary
data.text: Werner von Braun obituary Werner von Braun(65), German-born Nazi and American rocket scientist (V1/V2), diedof smoking. In 2005 Bob Ward authored “Dr. Space,' a biography ofvon Braun.(www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/sputnik/braun.html)(WSJ,6/16/05, p.D8)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Enterprise passed its first solo flight test by taking off atop aBoeing 747, separating and then touching down in California's MojaveDesert.(AP, 8/12/97)

data.title: NASA launched the
data.text: NASA launched the High Energy Astronomy Observatory 1 into Earth orbit. It continuedoperating until January 9, 1979.(http://heasarc.nasa.gov/docs/heao1/heao1.html)

data.title: The United States
data.text: The United States launched Voyager 2, an unmanned spacecraft carrying a 12-inch copperphonograph record containing greetings in dozens of languages,samples of music and sounds of nature. It was scheduled to passJupiter and Saturn.(V.D.-H.K.p.388)(MofE, 1978, p.41)(AP,8/20/97)(SFEC, 9/28/97, p.A14)

data.title: The United States
data.text: The United States launched the Voyager 1 spacecraft two weeks after launching itstwin, Voyager 2. (AP, 9/5/97)

data.title: Cosmos, a Soviet
data.text: Cosmos, a Soviet nuclear-powered satellite, was launched. It fell onto NorthernCanada on Jan. 24, 1978.(SSFC, 3/18/01, p.A1)

data.title: The experimental
data.text: The experimental space shuttle Enterprise glided to a bumpy but successful landing atEdwards Air Force Base in California. (AP, 10/26/97)

data.title: NASA named 35
data.text: NASA named 35 candidates to fly on the space shuttle, including Sally K. Ride, whobecame America's first woman in space, and Guion S. Bluford Jr., whobecame America's first black astronaut in space. Six women, out ofsome 3,000 original applicants, graduated from NASA's rigoroustraining program to become the 1st female astronauts in the spaceprogram.(AP,1/16/98)(www.astronautix.com/astrogrp/nas81978.htm)

data.title: Cosmos 954, a
data.text: Cosmos 954, a 4-month-old nuclear-powered Soviet satellite plunged through Earth'satmosphere and disintegrated, scattering radioactive debris overparts of northern Canada.(SSFC, 3/18/01, p.A1)(AP, 1/24/08)

data.title: The US Dept. of
data.text: The US Dept. of Defense launched the 1st of a constellation of satellites that latermade the backbone of the Global Positioning System (GPS). Ivan A.Getting (1912-2003), a military scientist, conceived the idea andBradford Parkinson of Stanford helped implement the system.(SFC, 10/18/03,p.A22)(http://msl.jpl.nasa.gov/Programs/gps.html)

data.title: Soyuz 28 carried 2
data.text: Soyuz 28 carried 2 cosmonauts to Salyut 6. Czech pilot Vladimir Remek became the firstnon-Russian, non-American in space.(HN, 3/2/99)(SC, 3/2/02)

data.title: US Seasat 1, the
data.text: US Seasat 1, the 1st oceanographic satellite, was launched into polar orbit.(www.n2yo.com/satellite.php?s=10967)

data.title: Soyuz 30 carried 2
data.text: Soyuz 30 carried 2 cosmonauts (1 Polish) to the Salyut 6 space station.(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soyuz_30)

data.title: The United States
data.text: The United States launched Pioneer Venus II, which carried scientific probes to studythe atmosphere of Venus.(HFA, '96, p.36)(AP, 8/8/99)

data.title: Sigmund Jahn
data.text: Sigmund Jahn became the first German in space when he blasted off aboard Russia’sSoyuz 31. (RTH, 8/26/99)

data.title: The weather
data.text: The weather satellite Nimbus-7 was launched with a Total Ozone MappingSpectrometer (TOMS) as one of its instruments.(NOHY, 3/90,p.142)(http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/earth/nimbus.html)

data.title: The American space
data.text: The American space probe Pioneer Venus I, orbiting Venus, began beaming back its firstinformation and picture of the planet to scientists in MountainView, Calif. data.title: The abandoned

data.title: Just 73 seconds
data.text: Just 73 seconds into its 10th launch, Americans watched in horror as the spaceshuttle Challenger (STS-51L) exploded in midair, killing its crew ofseven: Navy pilot Michael J. Smith, Commander Francis Scobee andmission specialist Ronald McNair, mission specialist EllisonOnizuka, first teacher in space Christa McAuliffe, payloadspecialist Gregory Jarvis and mission specialist Judith Resnik.President Ronald Reagan spoke to the nation from the Oval Officethat afternoon, explaining the tragedy to the nation'sschoolchildren: 'The future doesn't belong to the fainthearted. Itbelongs to the brave.... The crew of the space shuttle Challengerhonored us by the manner in which they lived their lives. We willnever forget them nor the last time we saw them this morning as theyprepared for their journey and waved good-bye and 'slipped the surlybonds of earth to touch the face of God.'' Space shuttle flightswere suspended until 1988. An independent U.S. commission blamed thedisaster on unusually cold temperatures that morning and the failureof the O-rings, a set of gaskets in the rocket boosters. Rocketengineer Bob Ebeling (d.2016 at 89) and Rocco Petrone (1926-2006),former Apollo program manager and Rockwell chief shuttle engineer,had cautioned against the launch fearing that low temperatures mighthave damaged the shuttle’s thermal protection tiles.(SFC, 12/18/96, p.A3)(AP, 1/28/98)(HNPD,1/28/00)(SFC, 9/1/06, p.B8)(SFC, 3/25/16, p.D7)

data.title: Just 73 seconds
data.text: Just 73 seconds into its 10th launch, Americans watched in horror as the spaceshuttle Challenger (STS-51L) exploded in midair, killing its crew ofseven: Navy pilot Michael J. Smith, Commander Francis Scobee andmission specialist Ronald McNair, mission specialist EllisonOnizuka, first teacher in space Christa McAuliffe, payloadspecialist Gregory Jarvis and mission specialist Judith Resnik.President Ronald Reagan spoke to the nation from the Oval Officethat afternoon, explaining the tragedy to the nation'sschoolchildren: 'The future doesn't belong to the fainthearted. Itbelongs to the brave.... The crew of the space shuttle Challengerhonored us by the manner in which they lived their lives. We willnever forget them nor the last time we saw them this morning as theyprepared for their journey and waved good-bye and 'slipped the surlybonds of earth to touch the face of God.'' Space shuttle flightswere suspended until 1988. An independent U.S. commission blamed thedisaster on unusually cold temperatures that morning and the failureof the O-rings, a set of gaskets in the rocket boosters. Rocketengineer Bob Ebeling (d.2016 at 89) and Rocco Petrone (1926-2006),former Apollo program manager and Rockwell chief shuttle engineer,had cautioned against the launch fearing that low temperatures mighthave damaged the shuttle’s thermal protection tiles.(SFC, 12/18/96, p.A3)(AP, 1/28/98)(HNPD,1/28/00)(SFC, 9/1/06, p.B8)(SFC, 3/25/16, p.D7)

data.title: NASA scientists
data.text: NASA scientists presented evidence that a meteorite from Mars (ALH 84001) that wasfound in Antarctica in 1984 contained organic minerals such ascarbonate globules, magnetite, iron sulfide and polycyclic aromatichydrocarbons. In 2001 Imre Friedmann (1921-2007), extrememicrobiologist, led a team of researchers to study the samemeteorite and claimed conclusive evidence that Mars had been teemingwith life 3.5 billion years ago.(SFC, 8/8/96, p.A6)(Econ, 6/30/07, p.96)1996-The $10 million Ansari XPrize was offered to encourage the development of space tourism. Thewinner was required to make the 1st private launch of 3-people to analtitude of 62.5 miles twice in 2 weeks. (SFC, 4/19/03, p.A2)(WSJ, 6/14/04, p.B1)

data.title: The Russian Soyuz
data.text: The Russian Soyuz TM-24 returned to Earth.(SC, 3/2/02)

data.title: Russia launched
data.text: Russia launched Zeya Start-1, a test satellite, aboard a modified SS-25 ballisticmissile from the new Svobodny cosmodrome in the Amur region ofeastern Siberia.(WSJ, 3/5/97, p.A1)(SC, 3/4/02)

data.title: Ashes of Star Trek
data.text: Ashes of Star Trek creator, Gene Roddenberry were launched into space, along with thoseof drug guru Timothy Leery.(MC, 3/12/02)

data.title: NASA officials
data.text: NASA officials announced they were cutting short the 16-day mission of spaceshuttle Columbia by 12 days because of a deteriorating andpotentially explosive power generator.(AP, 4/6/02)

data.title: Astronaut Jerry
data.text: Astronaut Jerry Linenger and cosmonaut Vasily Tsibliyev went on the firstU.S.-Russian space walk.(AP, 4/29/98)

data.title: , Space shuttle
data.text: , Space shuttle Atlantis blasted off on a mission to deliver urgently needed repairequipment and a fresh American astronaut to Russia's orbiting Mirstation. (AP, 5/15/98)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Atlantis docked with Russia's Mir station.(AP, 5/16/98)

data.title: The first flight
data.text: The first flight of NASA’s subscale remotely piloted X-36 Tailless Fighter AgilityResearch Aircraft took place.(www.dfrc.nasa.gov/gallery/Photo/X-36/index.html)

data.title: Russia's Mir space
data.text: Russia's Mir space station received a new oxygen generator and a fresh Americanastronaut, courtesy of space shuttle Atlantis.(AP, 5/17/98)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Atlantis undocked from the Russian Mir space station. (AP, 5/21/98)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Atlantis returned to Earth, bringing with it NASA astronaut JerryLinenger, who had spent four months aboard the Russian Mir spacestation. (AP, 5/24/98)

data.title: The Mars Pathfinder
data.text: The Mars Pathfinder landed and began to broadcast pictures of the red rocky landscape.The landing site was later named the Carl Sagan Memorial Station.(SFC, 7/5/97, p.A1)

data.title: The Columbia space
data.text: The Columbia space shuttle and it crew of 7 returned after a 16-day mission. On the Mirspace station, the 3-man crew struggled to stabilize a free-spinafter a cable to a key computer system was mistakenly pulled.(SFC, 7/18/97, p.A1,9)(AP, 7/17/98)

data.title: All key systems on
data.text: All key systems on the Russian space station Mir returned to near-normal, about 24hours after the already disabled spacecraft had lost power. (HN, 7/18/98)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Discovery was launched with a crew of six. A satellite was droppedoff to study the Earth’s ozone layer.(SFC, 8/8/97, p.A3)

data.title: A Russian capsule
data.text: A Russian capsule on a fix-it mission docked gingerly with the crippled Mir spacestation, bringing a new crew to salvage the orbiting outpost. (AP, 8/7/98)

data.title: Two cosmonauts
data.text: Two cosmonauts just returned from Mir (Vasily Tsibliyev and Alexander Lazutkin)rejected criticism that they were to blame for troubles aboard theaging, problem-plagued space station.(AP, 8/16/98)

data.title: A $64.8 million
data.text: A $64.8 million 890- lb. Lewis satellite was launched by NASA on a hoped-for 5-yearmission. It went into an uncontrolled spin on Aug 22 and wasexpected to fall and burn up in Earth’s atmosphere in Sep.(SFC, 9/27/97, p.A3)

data.title: NASA sent a Delta
data.text: NASA sent a Delta rocket aloft with the Ace solar observatory, Advanced CompositionExplorer. The 5-year $110 million project will go into orbit at apoint 1 million miles from Earth and 92 million miles from the Sunwhere the gravity of Earth and Sun balance.(SFC, 8/26/97, p.A2)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Atlantis was launched. Astronaut David Wolf scheduled to replaceMichael Foale on the Mir space station.(www.cnn.com/TECH/9709/25/shuttle.mir/)(SFC,9/27/97, p.A3)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Atlantis, docked with the problem-plagued Russian Mir station todrop off American David Wolf and pick up Michael Foale.(AP, 9/27/98)

data.title: Space-walking
data.text: Space-walking astronauts from the shuttle Columbia grabbed a spinning satellitewith their hands, enabling the cockpit crew to use the shuttle'srobot arm to return it to the cargo bay.(AP, 11/24/07)

data.title: Japan launched the
data.text: Japan launched the Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission satellite (TRMM) in a jointventure with NASA. Funding ended in 2004 a controlled de-orbit wasplanned.(SFC, 7/19/04, p.A4)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Columbia returned from a 16-day mission that had been marred by thebungled release of a satellite.(AP, 12/5/98)

data.title: The world’s first
data.text: The world’s first civilian spy satellite, EarlyBird I, was launched from Russia. Itwas built by EarthWatch Inc. of Longmont, Colo.(SFC, 12/25/97, p.A6)

data.title: NASA officially
data.text: NASA officially announced that John Glenn, the first American to orbit the Earth,would fly aboard the space shuttle later in the year.(AP, 1/16/99)

data.title: The Endeavour
data.text: The Endeavour space shuttle shot up on its way to meet with the Mir space station.Astronaut Andrew Thomas traded places with David Wolf for a 4-monthstint. (SFC, 1/23/98, p.A5)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Endeavour returned from Mir with its crew of 7.(SFEC, 2/1/98, p.A2)

data.title: NASA officials
data.text: NASA officials announced that the Lunar Prospector probe found the presence ofwater on the moon at the north and south poles. As much as 100million tons of water was estimated. They said that the water frozenin the loose soil of the moon might support a lunar base and a humancolony.(SFC, 3/6/98, p.A1)(WSJ, 3/6/98, p.A1)(AP,3/5/99)

data.title: Space Shuttle
data.text: Space Shuttle Discovery was launched and it planned to pick up astronaut AndrewThomas from the Mir space station.(WSJ, 6/3/98, p.A1)

data.title: Discovery completed
data.text: Discovery completed its 9th and final visit to Mir. Russian astronaut Talgat Musabayevpassed a 2-foot wrench to Andrew Thomas to take to the new int’l.space station.(SFC, 6/9/98, p.A3)

data.title: In New Mexico the
data.text: In New Mexico the $77 million Sloan Digital Sky Survey was reported to be about tostart probing the universe.(SFC, 6/9/98, p.A3)

data.title: A Lockheed Martin
data.text: A Lockheed Martin Titan 4A rocket exploded after takeoff at Cape Canaveral. The $300million rocket carried a spy satellite for the Air Force valued at$800 to $1 billion. The explosion was blamed on a momentary loss ofpower.(SFC, 8/13/98, p.A2)(SFC, 9/3/98, p.A3)

data.title: A $225 million
data.text: A $225 million rocket and communication satellite exploded after take-off at CapeCanaveral.(SFC, 8/27/98, p.A3)

data.title: The shuttle
data.text: The shuttle Discovery blasted off with 6 crew mates including John Glenn (77),the first American to orbit the Earth in 1962.(SFC, 10/30/98, p.A1)(WSJ, 10/30/98, p.A1)

data.title: The Deep Space I
data.text: The Deep Space I mission was launched. It would make a 2-year tour of the outer solarsystem propelled by an ion-propulsion system.(SFC, 8/28/97, p.A2)(www.space.com)

data.title: The shuttle
data.text: The shuttle Discovery landed in Cape Canaveral, Fla. After 9 days in space.(SFEC, 11/8/98, p.A2)

data.title: Phase 2 began in
data.text: Phase 2 began in the construction of the ISS. It would take 5 years,43 flights and 16 nations to assemble the outpost.The firsthuman crew arrived in November 2000.(SFC, 6/9/98, p.A3)(CSM, 11/22/18)

data.title: In Kazakhstan a
data.text: In Kazakhstan a Russian Proton booster rocket lifted up the first stage of the newISS called Zarya (Sunrise).(SFC, 11/20/98, p.A18)(SFC, 11/21/98, p.A13)

data.title: The shuttle
data.text: The shuttle Endeavour was launched with a crew of 6 from Cape Canaveral. Itcontained the 2nd component of the new ISS.(SFC, 12/4/98, p.A2)

data.title: The astronauts of
data.text: The astronauts of the Endeavour space shuttle attached Node 1 of the new space stationto the cargo block Zarya.(SFC, 12/7/98, p.A2)

data.title: The Endeavour
data.text: The Endeavour shuttle and crew returned to Cape Canaveral in a night time landingfollowing NASA’s first space station-building mission.(SFC, 12/16/98, p.A7)

data.title: The Stardust
data.text: The Stardust spacecraft lifted off aboard a Delta II rocket for its 7-yearjourney to gather particles from the Wild-2 comet.(SFC, 2/6/99, p.A8)(SFC, 2/8/99, p.A2)

data.title: The Liberty Bell 7
data.text: The Liberty Bell 7 Mercury capsule, which sank in 1961, was found 300 miles offshorefrom Cape Canaveral in 3 waters 3 miles deep.(SFC, 5/3/99, p.A2)

data.title: The Mir space
data.text: The Mir space station was to be allowed to burn up in the atmosphere later thisyear, but Pres. Yeltsin signed permission to keep the Mir spacestation aloft pending private financing.(SFC, 6/9/98, p.A3)(SFC, 5/25/99, p.A8)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Discovery was launched from Kennedy Space Center in Florida with 7astronauts from the US, Canada and Russia. The shuttle was on a10-day mission to stock the new space station. Julie Payette ofCanada flew on the 10-day mission.(SFC, 5/28/99, p.A2)(USAT, 7/26/99, p.14A)

data.title: Astronauts from
data.text: Astronauts from the space shuttle “Discovery' rigged cranes and other tools to theexterior of the international space station during a spacewalk;then, the astronauts entered the orbiting outpost for three days ofmaking repairs and delivering supplies.(AP, 5/30/00)

data.title: The Shuttle
data.text: The Shuttle Discover landed at Kennedy Space Center just after 2 a.m. followingthe first docking with the newISS.(SFEC, 6/6/99, p.A19)

data.title: Astronaut Charles obituary
data.text: Astronaut Charles obituary Astronaut Charles 'Pete' Conrad Junior, the third man to walk on the moon, died aftera motorcycle accident near Ojai, California; he was 69. (SFC, 7/9/99, p.A1)(AP, 7/8/00)

data.title: A Russian supply
data.text: A Russian supply ship for Mir was launched from Baikomur in Kazakstan. It proceededto successfully dock with Mir.(WSJ, 7/19/99, p.A1)

data.title: After 38 years at
data.text: After 38 years at the bottom of the Atlantic, astronaut Gus Grissom’s 'Liberty BellSeven' Mercury capsule was lifted to the surface. (AP, 7/20/00)

data.title: After a 2 day
data.text: After a 2 day delay the Chandra X-ray Observatory was launched from Cape Canaveralaboard the shuttle Columbia led by Commander Eileen Collins, thefirst woman to command a US space flight.(SFC, 7/23/99, p.A3)(AP, 7/23/00)

data.title: The Columbia space
data.text: The Columbia space shuttle landed at Cape Canaveral after a 3 day mission to deploy theChandra X-ray telescope.(SFC, 7/28/99, p.A3)

data.title: NASA controllers
data.text: NASA controllers planned to send the $63 million Lunar Prospector crashing into theMawson crater located in the Moon’s south pole. They hoped to churnup some water vapor for possible detection. Evidence of the crash at2:51 PDT was not detected.(SFC, 6/3/99, p.A4)(SFEC, 8/1/99, p.A3)

data.title: The Russian Mir
data.text: The Russian Mir space station was closed down as the last crew undocked.(SFC, 8/28/99, p.A10)

data.title: NASA temporarily
data.text: NASA temporarily grounded its space shuttle fleet after inspections had uncovereddamaged wires that could endanger a mission. (AP, 9/3/00)

data.title: China completed
data.text: China completed its first unmanned test of a spacecraft. The Shenzhou 1, or 'DivineVessel,' was launched at the Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center inGansu province.(SFEC, 11/21/99, p.A1)

data.title: The shuttle
data.text: The shuttle Discovery was launched following 9 delays from Cape Canaveral with 7astronauts on a mission to repair the Hubble Space Telescope.(SFC, 12/20/99, p.A3)

data.title: Space shuttle
data.text: Space shuttle Discovery landed at Cape Canaveral, Fla., following a successfulrepair of the Hubble Space Telescope.(SFC, 12/28/99, p.A3)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Endeavour lifted into orbit with a crew of six under commander KevinKregel and a mission to map the Earth.(SFC, 2/12/00, p.A4)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Endeavour and its crew of 6 returned to Cape Canaveral with over aweeks worth of radar images to map Earth.(SFC, 2/23/00, p.A2)

data.title: Two Russian
data.text: Two Russian cosmonauts docked with Mir. The destruction of the space station wasdelayed after MirCorp. of Amsterdam agreed in Feb. to pay $10-20million to lease commercial rights.(SFC, 4/7/00, p.D2)(SFEC, 6/11/00, p.T12)

data.title: The shuttle
data.text: The shuttle Atlantis lifted off with 7 astronauts on a mission to fix the Int’l.Space Station.(SFC, 5/20/00, p.A7)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Atlantis landed at Cape Canaveral in the early morning dark after asuccessful overhaul of the ISS.(SFC, 5/30/00, p.A3)

data.title: The $670 million,
data.text: The $670 million, 17-ton, Compton Gamma Ray Observatory was directed to a suicideplunge.(SSFC, 1/27/08,p.A4)(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compton_Gamma_Ray_Observatory)

data.title: The Russian-made
data.text: The Russian-made Zvezda service module for the ISS was launched fromthe Baikonur site in Kazakstan.(SFC, 7/11/00, p.A8)(SFC, 7/12/00, p.A8)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Atlantis blasted into orbit to deliver supplies to the new int’l.space station.(SFC, 9/9/00, p.A3)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Atlantis returned after hauling in 3 tons of equipment for theISS.(WSJ, 9/21/00, p.A1)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Discovery landed at Edwards Air Force Base following the 100thshuttle flight and work on the ISS.(SFC, 10/25/00, p.A3)

data.title: American astronaut
data.text: American astronaut Bill Shepherd and Yuri Gidzenko and Sergei Krikalev of Russiarocketed into orbit aboard a Soyuz rocket for the Int’l. SpaceStation for a 4-month stay. They would become the first residents ofthe international space station.(www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/shepherd.html)(SFC, 10/31/00,p.A12)(AP, 10/31/01)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Endeavour took off to the ISS with a crew of 5 toinstall new solar panels.(SFC, 12/1/00, p.A14)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Endeavour landed in Florida following its mission to install solarpanels on the ISS.(WSJ, 12/12/00, p.A1)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Atlantis took off with the Destiny module, a laboratory compartment,for the ISS.(SFC, 2/8/01, p.A3)

data.title: Space Shuttle Atlantis
data.text: Space Shuttle Atlantis Space Shuttle Atlantis landed at Edwards Air Force Base following a 13-day missionto the ISS.(SFC, 2/21/01, p.A5)

data.title: X-33
data.text: X-33 NASA announced the cancellation of the X-33, a new heavy-lift orbiting spacecraft. TheX-34, a reusable vehicle, and the X-38, a rescue vehicle, were alsocancelled due to budget constraints.(WSJ, 3/7/01, p.A22)

data.title: Leonardo
data.text: Leonardo The space shuttle Discovery lifted off with supplies for the ISS in anew Italian module named Leonardo. The 12-day mission also includeda fresh crew of 3 for the station.(SFC, 3/9/01, p.A2)(WSJ, 3/9/01, p.A1)

data.title: Russia's orbiting
data.text: Russia's orbiting 135-ton Mir space station ended its 15-year odyssey with a fieryplunge into the South Pacific between Chile and New Zealand.(SFC, 3/23/01, p.A1)(AP, 3/23/02)

data.title: India launched a
data.text: India launched a rocket carrying a communications satellite.(SFC, 4/19/01, p.A11)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Endeavour went into orbit with 7 astronauts on an 11-day mission toinstall a billion-dollar robot arm on the ISS.(SFC, 4/20/01, p.A6)

data.title: A Russian Soyuz
data.text: A Russian Soyuz rocket lifted off for the ISS with Dennis Tito(60), who paid some $20 million, for the experience. Tito was thefounder of the Wilshire Associates investment firm.(SSFC, 4/29/01, p.A15)

data.title: NASA scientists
data.text: NASA scientists reported that they had contacted the Pioneer 10 spacecraft, launchedin 1972, after 8 months of no communication. (SFC, 4/30/01, p.A7)

data.title: The Soyuz-32,
data.text: The Soyuz-32, carrying multimillionaire Dennis Tito and 2 Russian astronauts,docked with the ISS.(SFC, 5/1/01, p.B3)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Endeavour landed at Edwards Air Force Base in the Mohave Desertfollowing the installation of the billion-dollar robot arm on theISS.(SFC, 5/2/01, p.A4)

data.title: NASA launched its
data.text: NASA launched its 16-foot, 1,800-pound Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe (WMAP) toorbit the Sun and to scan the universe for the faint afterglow ofCreation by measuring variations in radiation temperature of up to20 millionths of a degree. In 2003 it allowed scientists tocalculate the age of the universe at 13.7 billion years.(WSJ, 6/28/01, p.A16)(AP, 6/30/02)(SFC, 2/12/03,p.A4)

data.title: shuttle Atlantis took off
data.text: shuttle Atlantis took off The US space shuttle Atlantis took off with a crew of 5 to deliver a portal forspacewalks to the ISS Alpha.(SFC, 7/13/01, p.A3)(SFC, 7/14/01, p.C1)

data.title: NASA launched Helios
data.text: NASA launched Helios NASA launched an unmanned solar-powered plane named Helios over Hawaii.(WSJ, 7/16/01, p.A1)

data.title: Space shuttle blasted off
data.text: Space shuttle blasted off Space shuttle Discovery blasted off from Cape Canaveral with supplies and a freshcrew for the ISS.(SFC, 8/11/01, p.A4)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Discovery returned and brought home 3 crew members, Yuri Usachev,Susan Helms, and Jim Voss, who had spent nearly 6 months on theISS.(SFC, 8/23/01, p.A7)

data.title: A Russian module
data.text: A Russian module docked with space station Alpha 2 days after its launch fromKazakstan.(SFC, 9/17/01, p.A18)

data.title: A US Taurus
data.text: A US Taurus rocket, made by Orbital Sciences, carrying a NASA satellite failedto launch and probably plunged into the Indian ocean.(SFC, 9/22/01, p.A20)

data.title: In Kazakstan a
data.text: In Kazakstan a 3-person Russian-French crew blasted off for the Int’l. SpaceStation in a Russian Soyuz spacecraft. The crew included ClaudieHaignere, who in 1996 became the 1st Frenchwoman in space.(SFC, 10/22/01, p.B2)

data.title: NASA launched space
data.text: NASA launched space shuttle Endeavour to deliver a new 3-man crew to the Alpha spacestation. Russian cosmonaut Yuri Onufrienko flew to replace DougCulbertson as skipper.(WSJ, 12/6/01, p.A1)(SFC, 12/8/01, p.A2)

data.title: Jason-1, a
data.text: Jason-1, a satellite for tracking rising sea levels, was launched as a joint USand French effort. Its useful life ended in 2013.(SFC, 7/4/13, p.D3)

data.title: NASA agreed in
data.text: NASA agreed in principle to let Russia’s space agency send Mark Shuttleworth, aSouth Africa Internet tycoon, to the space station in April for some$20 million.(WSJ, 12/12/01, p.A1)

data.title: Space shuttle
data.text: Space shuttle Endeavour returned to Cape Canaveral following A 12-day mission fora crew change at the ISS.(SFC, 12/18/01, p.A4)(WSJ, 12/18/01, p.A1)

data.title: The 3.5-ton
data.text: The 3.5-ton satellite Extreme Ultraviolet Explorer (EUNE), launched in 1992,broke up in Earth’s atmosphere over Egypt. It had surveyed theentire Milky Way and beyond and transmitted date until Jan 31 2001.(SFC, 1/30/02,p.A2)(www.cbc.ca/health/story/2002/01/31/satellite020131.html)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Columbia with 7 astronauts blasted into orbit on an 11-day missionthat included work on the Hubble Space Telescope.(SFC, 3/2/02, p.A3)

data.title: Envisat
data.text: Envisat ('Environmental Satellite'), an Earth-observing satellite, waslaunched aboard an Ariane 5 from the Guyana Space Center in Kourou,French Guyana. After losing contact with the satellite on 8 April 2012,the European Space Agency formally announced the end ofEnvisat's mission on 9 May 2012.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Envisat)

data.title: Astronauts
data.text: Astronauts successfully replaced a power-control unit on the Hubble spacetelescope.(WSJ, 3/7/02, p.A1)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Atlantis took off for an 11-day mission to the ISS carryinglatticework and a rail car.(SFC, 4/9/02, p.A3)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Columbia's astronauts released the Hubble Space Telescope into orbitafter five days of repairs.(AP, 3/9/07)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Atlantis returned to Earth after installing the first girder in whateventually will be a giant framework at the international spacestation.(AP, 4/19/03)

data.title: Striking new
data.text: Striking new images from the upgraded Hubble Space Telescope were unveiled.(SFC, 5/1/02, p.A9)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Endeavour launched from Cape Canaveral carrying 7 new residents forthe ISS.(SFC, 6/6/02, p.A7)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Endeavour returned to Earth with one Russian and two Americancrewmen who'd spent six and a-half months aboard the internationalspace station.(AP, 6/19/03)

data.title: Moon rocks were stolen
data.text: Moon rocks were stolen Moon rocks were stolen from a NASA safe. They were recovered in July at a hotel inOrlando, Fl. 4 men were later convicted and sentenced to prisonterms. 3 young NASA employees, led by Thad Roberts (25) had stolen aquarter pound of moon rocks and tried selling them online to aBelgian collector, who alerted the FBI. In 2011 Ben Mezrich authored“Sex on the Moon: The Amazing Story Behind the Most Audacious Heistin History.'(SSFC, 7/17/11,p.F5)(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stolen_and_missing_moon_rocks)

data.title: A new Lockheed
data.text: A new Lockheed Martin Atlas V rocket launched a 4-ton French communicationssatellite into orbit.(WSJ, 8/23/02, p.A1)

data.title: Space shuttle
data.text: Space shuttle Atlantis carried 6 astronauts and a 14-ton girder for installationon the ISS.(ADN, 10/8/02, p.A4)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle 'Atlantis' arrived at the international space station, bringing withit a 14-ton girder.(AP, 10/9/03)

data.title: In northern Russia
data.text: In northern Russia a Soyuz-U rocket carrying an EU research communications satelliteexploded several seconds after liftoff from a launch pad, killingone soldier.(AP, 10/16/02)(WSJ, 10/17/02, p.A1)

data.title: Space shuttle
data.text: Space shuttle Atlantis returned to Earth following an 11-day mission to the int’l.space station.(SFC, 10/19/02, p.A16)

data.title: Space shuttle
data.text: Space shuttle Endeavour arrived at the international space station, delivering oneAmerican and two Russians, and another girder for the orbitingoutpost.(AP, 11/25/03)

data.title: The Astra-1K
data.text: The Astra-1K satellite was launched atop a Russian Proton rocket from theBaikonur cosmodrome in the former Soviet republic of Kazakhstan. Theworld's largest communications satellite, manufactured by France'sAlcatel Space corporation for Societe Europeene des Satellites ofLuxembourg, was lost after it went into the wrong orbit. (AP, 11/26/02)(WSJ, 11/27/02, p.A1)

data.title: Space shuttle
data.text: Space shuttle Endeavour returned to Earth along with space station voyagers PeggyWhitsun, Valery Korzun and Sergei Treschev. (SSFC, 12/8/02, p.A14)

data.title: China launched its
data.text: China launched its Shenzhou IV spacecraft in a test launch to prepare for manned spacevoyages.(SFC, 12/30/02, p.A8)2002-NASA removed 5 of 9 safetypanel members and 2 consultants following a report that safetyproblems loomed if the agency’s budget was not increased.(SSFC, 2/3/03, p.A1)2002-NASA said yes to a $2.5billion plan for a successor to the Hubble space telescope, launchedin 1990, that would use infra-red, rather than visible light, to beready in 2010. By 2011 the James Webb space telescope, now costing$8.8 billion, was still in the workshop with an estimated launch in2018.(Econ, 11/12/11, p.94)2002-Gary McKinnon was caughtin London and after breaking into 97 US military and NASA computers,while allegedly searching for UFO’s. His hacking from 2001-2002caused an estimated $700,000 of damage. In 2008 McKinnon (42) wasdiagnosed with Asperger’s syndrome. He also lost an appeal againstbeing extradited to the US to face charges. In 2009 he offered toplead guilty to a criminal charge in Britain to avoid extradition tothe United States.(SFC, 7/31/08, p.A14)(AP, 1/12/09)(Econ, 8/8/09,p.51)

data.title: The shuttle
data.text: The shuttle Columbia carried a crew of 7 for a 16-day mission. Col. Ilan Ramonwas aboard as Israel's 1st astronaut. The mission ended in tragedyon Feb. 1, when the shuttle broke up during its return descent,killing all seven crew members.(SFC, 1/17/03, p.A2)(AP, 1/16/04)

data.title: NASA launched a
data.text: NASA launched a spacecraft into orbit to measure all the radiation streaming towardEarth from the sun. The small satellite is called Sorce — for SolarRadiation and Climate Experiment.(AP, 1/25/04)

data.title: Space shuttle
data.text: Space shuttle Columbia broke apart in flames over Texas, killing all 7 astronautsjust 16 minutes before they were supposed to glide to ground inFlorida. The astronauts included Michael P. Anderson (b.1959), DavidM. Brown (b.1956), Laurel Clark (b.1962), Kalpana Chawla (b.1962),Rick Husband (b.1957), William C. McCool (b.1961) and Ilan Ramon(b.1954).(AP, 2/1/03)(SSFC, 2/2/03, p.A8)

data.title: In Kazakstan
data.text: In Kazakstan Progress M-47 lifted off atop a Soyuz-U rocket to deliver suppliesto the ISS.(SFC, 2/3/03, p.A5)

data.title: An investigative
data.text: An investigative panel found that superheated air almost certainly seeped through abreach in space shuttle Columbia's left wing and possibly its wheelcompartment during the craft's fiery descent, resulting in thedeaths of all seven astronauts.(AP, 2/13/04)

data.title: NASA released
data.text: NASA released video taken aboard Columbia that had miraculously survived the fierydestruction of the space shuttle with the loss of all sevenastronauts; in the footage, four of the crew members can be seendoing routine chores and admiring the view outside the cockpit.(AP, 2/28/04)

data.title: Burt Rutan,
data.text: Burt Rutan, aircraft designer, unveiled SpaceShipOne, a rocket-poweredspacecraft. He hoped to win the $10 million 1996 X Prize, offeredfor the 1st private launch of 3-people to an altitude of 62.5 milestwice in 2 weeks.(SFC, 4/19/03, p.A2)

data.title: Russia lunched a
data.text: Russia lunched a Soyuz rocket with a 2-man crew to keep the space station operatingwhile Shuttle flights are suspended.(WSJ, 4/28/03, A1)

data.title: NASA launched a
data.text: NASA launched a Mars Exploration Rover named Spirit, the 1st of 2. Spirit arrived onMars in January 2004.(WSJ, 6/11/03, p.A1)(SFC, 6/12/03, p.A1)(AP,6/10/08)

data.title: A chunk of foam
data.text: A chunk of foam insulation fired at shuttle wing parts blew open a gaping 16-inchhole, yielding what one member of the Columbia investigation teamsaid was the 'smoking gun' proving what brought down the spaceshipon Feb 1.(AP, 7/7/04)

data.title: NASA's 2nd Mars
data.text: NASA's 2nd Mars lander, named Opportunity, was launched.(SFC, 7/8/03, p.A1)

data.title: Russian cosmonaut
data.text: Russian cosmonaut Yuri Malenchenko, aboard the international space center, married hisearthbound bride, Ekaterina Dmitriev, who was at Johnson SpaceCenter in Houston, in the first wedding ever conducted from space.(AP, 8/11/08)

data.title: NASA launched the
data.text: NASA launched the largest-diameter infrared telescope ever in space. NASA showed the1st images from the $670 million Spitzer Space Telescope on Dec 18.(WSJ, 8/26/03, p.A1)(SFC, 12/19/03, p.A2)

data.title: NASA presented a
data.text: NASA presented a 'return to flight' plan for the shuttle fleet.(WSJ, 9/8/03, p.A1)

data.title: NASA’s $1.5
data.text: NASA’s $1.5 billion Galileo mission ended a 14-year exploration of the solarsystem's largest planet and its moons with the spacecraft crashingby design into Jupiter at 108,000 mph.(SFC, 9/22/03, p.B8)(AP, 9/21/04)

data.title: In China Shenzhou
data.text: In China Shenzhou 5 launched into orbit with air force Lt. Col. Yang Liwei (38)aboard, making China the third nation to put a human in space on itsown, after the former Soviet Union and the United States. The launchwas made from the space center at Jiuquan. His capsule landed inMongolia the next day.(AP, 10/15/03)(SFC, 10/16/03, p.A3)(SSFC,7/15/07, p.D5)(Econ, 10/24/09, SR p.13)

data.title: Soyuz TMA-3
data.text: Soyuz TMA-3 Russia launched a Soyuz capsule from Kazakhstan with a 3-man crew for the ISSstation. Aboard were an American, a Russian and a Spaniard.(SSFC, 10/19/03, p.A2)

data.title: Columbia Space Shuttle Crew Remembered
data.text: Columbia Space Shuttle Crew Remembered The seven astronauts who died in the February 1 Columbia shuttle disaster werehonored with the unveiling of their names carved into the nationalSpace Mirror Memorial in Florida.(AP, 10/28/08)

data.title: A Soyuz space
data.text: A Soyuz space capsule with 3 astronauts landed in Kazakhstan.(SFC, 10/28/03, p.A1)

data.title: The British Beagle
data.text: The British Beagle 2 spacecraft landed on Mars. The 73-pound lander was launched by theEuropean Space Agency June 2. Contact with the Charles Darwin probewas lost soon after it separated from its European Space Agency MarsExpress mother ship on Dec 19. The mother ship went into orbit for aplanned 2 years of photography.(SFC, 12/25/03, p.A1)(SFC, 12/26/03, p.A2)(SFC,12/27/03, p.A2)

data.title: The expected
data.text: The expected completion date of the $17.4 billion ISS. The costwas estimated up in 1998 to $24.7 billion, and possibly delayed by 3years.(SFC, 4/24/98, p.A10)

data.title: Drop pressure in the ISS
data.text: Drop pressure in the ISS Pressure in theISS continued to drop.(WSJ, 1/9/04, p.A1)

data.title: Pres. Bush would send humans back to the moon
data.text: Pres. Bush would send humans back to the moon Pres. Bush proposed a new space program that would send humans back to the moonby 2015 and establish a base to Mars and beyond. Bush said he wouldseek $12 billion for the initial stages of the plan.(SFC, 1/15/04, p.A1)(WSJ, 1/15/04, p.A1)

data.title: The NASA Spirit
data.text: The NASA Spirit rover rolled onto the surface of Mars for the first time since thevehicle bounced to a landing nearly two weeks earlier.(AP, 1/15/05)

data.title: NASA said it would
data.text: NASA said it would not send another shuttle mission to service and repair the HubbleSpace Telescope.(SFC, 1/17/04, p.A1)

data.title: NASA said it lost
data.text: NASA said it lost contact with the Mars spirit rover.(WSJ, 1/23/04, p.A1)

data.title: A 2nd NASA rover
data.text: A 2nd NASA rover was set to land on Mars.(SFC, 1/23/04, p.A14)

data.title: The European Space
data.text: The European Space Agency launched its Rosetta lander. It was intended to land on comet67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko in May, 2014.(SFC, 7/18/05, p.A4)

data.title: A NASA unpiloted
data.text: A NASA unpiloted X-43A jet, part of its Hyper-X program, reached a record speed of5,200 mph, Mach 6.83, after a rocket boosted it to 3,500 mph. Itused a new engine called a supersonic-combustion ramjet, orscramjet.(SSFC, 3/28/04, p.A3)(Econ, 3/27/04, p.80)(SFC,11/10/04, p.A2)

data.title: A Russian rocket
data.text: A Russian rocket roared into space carrying an American, a Russian and a Dutchman tothe international space station on the 3rd manned mission since thehalt of the US shuttle program.(SFC, 4/19/04, p.A5)(AP, 4/19/05)

data.title: The NASA Gravity
data.text: The NASA Gravity Probe B satellite, designed by Stanford researchers, was launched totest Einstein's General Theory of Relativity.(SFC, 4/21/04, p.A7)

data.title: SpaceShipOne
data.text: SpaceShipOne lifted off from the Mojave Desert in the initial stage of theworld's first attempted commercial space flight. SpaceShipOnereached 62.21 miles. It was designed by legendary aerospace designerBurt Rutan and was built with more than $20 million in funding bybillionaire Paul Allen. It was piloted by Michael Melvill.(AP, 6/21/04)(WSJ, 6/22/04, p.A1)

data.title: The Cassini
data.text: The Cassini spacecraft sent back photographs of Saturn's shimmering rings.(AP, 7/1/05)

data.title: NASA’s $260 million
data.text: NASA’s $260 million Genesis space capsule crashed in the Utah desert after its parachutefailed to open. It carried a cargo of solar wind particles.(SFC, 9/9/04, p.A1)

data.title: Mike Melvill
data.text: Mike Melvill piloted SpaceShipOne, designed by Burt Rutan, climbed to 337,500feet in the 1st leg of an attempt to capture the $10 million XPrize. The prize required a 2nd success within 2 weeks. (SFC, 9/30/04, p.A4)

data.title: Mike Melvill
data.text: Mike Melvill piloted SpaceShipOne, designed by Burt Rutan, climbed to 367,442feet in a 2nd leg and captured the $10 million Ansari X Prize. (SFC, 10/5/04, p.A1)(Econ, 10/9/04, p.75)

data.title: Gordon Cooper
data.text: Gordon Cooper (b.1927), US astronaut in the Mercury program, died in Ventura, Ca.He piloted Faith 7 around Earth on May 15-16, 1963.(SFC, 10/5/04, p.B7)

data.title: A Russian rocket
data.text: A Russian rocket lifted off in Kazakhstan carrying 2 Russians and an American toreplace the crew of the ISS.(SFC, 10/14/04, p.A2)

data.title: A Soyuz capsule,
data.text: A Soyuz capsule, carrying 2 Russians and an American, landed in Kazakhstan. The crewhad spent 6 months at the ISS.(SSFC, 10/24/04, p.A7)

data.title: Russia launched an
data.text: Russia launched an unmanned cargo ship to the ISS.(WSJ, 12/24/04, p.A1)

data.title: The Russian
data.text: The Russian unmanned cargo ship, Progress M-51, docked at the int’l. spacestation with fresh supplies.(SFC, 12/25/04, p.A5)2004-Greg Klerkx authored “Lostin Space: The Fall of NASA and the Dream of a Space Age.(SSFC, 12/12/04, p.E6)

data.title: NASA launched its
data.text: NASA launched its Deep Impact spacecraft from Cape Canaveral, Fla. It was scheduled tolaunch an 820-poind impactor vehicle at Comet Tempel-1 on July 4.(WSJ, 1/13/05, p.D8)

data.title: The European space
data.text: The European space probe Huygens landed on Saturn's moon Titan, sending back images ofwhat scientists were calling the strangest landscape in the solarsystem. Pictures showed a pale orange surface covered by a thin hazeof methane and what appears to be a methane sea complete withislands and a mist-shrouded coastline.(AP,1/15/05)(http://huygens.esa.int/science-e/www/object/index.cfm?fobjectid=36280)

data.title: Pres. Bush picked
data.text: Pres. Bush picked Johns Hopkins physicist Michael Griffin to lead NASA.(SFC, 3/12/05, p.A8)

data.title: A Russian Soyuz-FG
data.text: A Russian Soyuz-FG rocket lifted off at Baikonur, Kazakhstan, carrying 3 men to theISS.(SFC, 4/15/05, p.A3)

data.title: A 3-man crew from
data.text: A 3-man crew from the ISS landed in northern Kazakhstan.(SFC, 4/25/05, p.A3)

data.title: A NASA spacecraft
data.text: A NASA spacecraft collided with a comet half the size of Manhattan, creating abrilliant cosmic smashup that capped a risky voyage to uncover thebuilding blocks of life on Earth.(Reuters, 7/4/05)

data.title: A fuel gauge that
data.text: A fuel gauge that mistakenly read full instead of empty forced NASA to call off thefirst shuttle launch in 2½ years.(AP, 7/13/06)

data.title: Discovery and
data.text: Discovery and seven astronauts blasted into orbit on America's first manned spaceshot since the 2003 Columbia disaster, ending a painful, 2 1/2-yearshutdown devoted to making the shuttle less risky and NASA moresafety-conscious. Its mission was to resupply the space station anddeliver a new gyroscope and storage platform.(AP, 7/26/05)(SFC, 7/27/05, p.A1)

data.title: Discovery and its
data.text: Discovery and its crew of seven glided back to Earth ending a 14-day test of spaceshuttle safety. NASA’s STS 114 flight was shadowed by the ghosts ofColumbia(AP, 8/9/05)(Econ, 8/13/05, p.68)

data.title: A Russian space
data.text: A Russian space capsule with American tourist Gregory Olsen aboard docked with theinternational space station.(AP, 10/4/06)

data.title: US millionaire
data.text: US millionaire scientist Gregory Olsen and a two-man, Russian-American crewreturned from the international space station to Earth in a swift,bone-jarring descent in Kazakhstan.(AP, 10/11/05)

data.title: The EU launched
data.text: The EU launched the first satellite in its Galileo navigation program, whichofficials expect one day will end the continent's reliance on the USGlobal Positioning System. A Soyuz rocket, launched from Baikonur,Kazakhstan, carried the 1st of an expected 30 satellites.(AP, 12/28/05)(Econ, 7/15/06, p.53)

data.title: The NASA space
data.text: The NASA space capsule, Stardust, returned safely to Earth in a desert near SaltLake City with the first dust ever fetched from a comet, a cosmicbounty that scientists hope will yield clues to how the solar systemformed.(http://stardust.jpl.nasa.gov/photo/er.html)(AP,1/15/06)

data.title: NASA launched its
data.text: NASA launched its New Horizons spacecraft on a mission to Pluto following a 2-daydelay. Scientists won't be able to receive data on Pluto until atleast July 2015, the earliest date the mission is expected toarrive. The spacecraft carried ashes of Clyde Tombaugh (1906-1997),the man who discovered Pluto.(SFC, 1/20/06, p.A5)(SFC, 7/13/15, p.A7)

data.title: Intelsat acquires PanAmSat
data.text: Intelsat acquires PanAmSat Intelsat acquires fellow fixed satellite service provider PanAmSat for $6.4 billion.

data.title: The US space
data.text: The US space shuttle Discovery took off at the Kennedy Space Center in CapeCanaveral, Florida, with 7 astronauts. Up to six pieces of debristhat could be foam insulation fell off Discovery's troublesomeexternal fuel tank minutes after liftoff. News arrived that NorthKorea had launched test missiles [see July 5].(AFP, 7/5/06)(SFC, 7/5/06, p.A3)

data.title: North Korea
data.text: North Korea test-fired a long-range missile that may be capable of reachingAmerica, but it failed seconds after launch. North Korea also testedshorter range missiles in an exercise the White House termed 'aprovocation' but not an immediate threat. The early morning testscame as the US celebrated the Fourth of July and just minutes aheadof the US launch of the space shuttle Discovery.(AP, 7/4/06)(AP, 7/5/06)(SFC, 7/5/06, p.A1)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Discovery docked with the international space station, bringing withit European Space Agency astronaut Thomas Reiter, who began asix-month stay aboard the station.(AP, 7/6/07)

data.title: Discovery
data.text: Discovery astronauts Piers Sellers and Michael Fossum went on a 7 1/2-hourspacewalk to test a repair technique for space shuttles.(AP, 7/8/07)

data.title: The space shuttle
data.text: The space shuttle Discovery undocked from the international space station.(AP, 7/15/07)

data.title: Anousheh Ansari
data.text: Anousheh Ansari (40), an Iranian-American telecommunications entrepreneur, took offon a Russian rocket bound for the international space station,becoming the world's first paying female space tourist. Aboard thespace station, an oxygen generator overheated and spilled a toxicirritant, forcing the crew to don masks and gloves in the firstemergency ever declared aboard the 8-year-old orbiting outpost.(AP, 9/18/07)

data.title: After a two-day
data.text: After a two-day journey, space shuttle Discovery reached the international spacestation for a weeklong stay.(AP, 12/11/07)

data.title: Space shuttle
data.text: Space shuttle Discovery and its seven-member crew landed in Florida after asmooth, 13-day flight to rewire the International Space Station.(AFP, 12/23/06)(AP, 12/22/07)

data.title: China destroyed
data.text: China destroyed its Feng Yun 1-C, an aging weather satellite launched in 1999, witha ballistic missile 537 miles above the Earth. The impact createdabout 28% of the junk currently floating in space. The US haltedsuch tests in 1985 for fear of creating debris deadly to spacecraft.(WSJ, 1/19/07, p.A1)(Econ, 1/27/07, p.38)(Econ,1/19/08, p.26)

data.title: NASA astronaut Lisa
